articles.headline: Biden Will Nominate First Women to Lead Treasury and Intelligence, and First Latino to Run Homeland Security
articles.snippet: John Kerry, the former secretary of state, will be the international climate czar, signaling the new administration’s commitment to fighting climate change.
articles.abstract: John Kerry, the former secretary of state, will be the international climate czar, signaling the new administration’s commitment to fighting climate change.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. plans to name Janet L. Yellen as Treasury secretary, a nomination that would put a woman in charge of the Treasury for the first time in its 231-year history.
articles.byline: By Michael Crowley and Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: How Misinformation ‘Superspreaders’ Seed False Election Theories
articles.snippet: Researchers have found that a small group of social media accounts are responsible for the spread of a disproportionate amount of the false posts about voter fraud.
articles.abstract: Researchers have found that a small group of social media accounts are responsible for the spread of a disproportionate amount of the false posts about voter fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the morning of Nov. 5, Eric Trump, one of the president’s sons, asked his Facebook followers to report cases of voter fraud with the hashtag, Stop the Steal. His post was shared over 5,000 times.

articles.headline: As Customers Move Online, So Does the Holiday Shopping Season
articles.snippet: Empty stores are turning into fulfillment centers and the market for warehouse space is booming, as the pandemic rockets the retail industry into its e-commerce future.
articles.abstract: Empty stores are turning into fulfillment centers and the market for warehouse space is booming, as the pandemic rockets the retail industry into its e-commerce future.
articles.lead_paragraph: The holidays will look different at Macy’s this year. The Thanksgiving Day parade will proceed without spectators, and Santa Claus will not be reviewing Christmas wish lists from his usual perch on 34th Street.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Sapna Maheshwari

articles.headline: Janet Yellen, Biden’s Expected Treasury Pick, Has Broken More Than Gender Barriers
articles.snippet: The former Fed chair, a labor market expert, appears poised to become one of few people to ever have wielded economic power from the White House, the Federal Reserve and the president’s cabinet.
articles.abstract: The former Fed chair, a labor market expert, appears poised to become one of few people to ever have wielded economic power from the White House, the Federal Reserve and the president’s cabinet.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Janet L. Yellen became an economist at a time when few women entered the profession and fewer still rose in a male-dominated environment. She is now poised to become the first female Treasury secretary and one of few people to ever have wielded economic power from the White House, the Federal Reserve and the president’s cabinet.

articles.headline: Trump Administration Approves Start of Formal Transition to Biden
articles.snippet: A key official designated President-elect Joe Biden as the apparent winner after Michigan certified his victory there and President Trump lost another court decision in Pennsylvania.
articles.abstract: A key official designated President-elect Joe Biden as the apparent winner after Michigan certified his victory there and President Trump lost another court decision in Pennsylvania.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s government on Monday authorized President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. to begin a formal transition process after Michigan certified Mr. Biden as its winner, a strong sign that the president’s last-ditch bid to overturn the results of the election was coming to an end.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Maggie Haberman, Nick Corasaniti and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: After Chaotic 4 Years, Wall St. Is Itching to Unfollow @realDonaldTrump
articles.snippet: President Trump turned his Twitter feed into a singular source of market volatility. Now, investors are looking forward to markets free of presidential tweets.
articles.abstract: President Trump turned his Twitter feed into a singular source of market volatility. Now, investors are looking forward to markets free of presidential tweets.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the closing weeks of the presidential campaign, President Trump began telling his supporters that if former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. was elected, market mayhem would follow.

articles.headline: Evidence Builds That an Early Mutation Made the Pandemic Harder to Stop
articles.snippet: Scientists were initially skeptical that a mutation made the coronavirus more contagious. But new research has changed many of their minds.
articles.abstract: Scientists were initially skeptical that a mutation made the coronavirus more contagious. But new research has changed many of their minds.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the coronavirus swept across the world, it picked up random alterations to its genetic sequence. Like meaningless typos in a script, most of those mutations made no difference in how the virus behaved.
articles.byline: By James Glanz, Benedict Carey and Hannah Beech

articles.headline: Latinos, Long Dismissed in Hollywood, Push to Make Voices Heard
articles.snippet: To many Latinos in Hollywood, every gain seems to be followed by a setback. The writer Tanya Saracho and others involved in the Untitled Latinx Project want to change that.
articles.abstract: To many Latinos in Hollywood, every gain seems to be followed by a setback. The writer Tanya Saracho and others involved in the Untitled Latinx Project want to change that.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tanya Saracho landed her first television writing job on the Lifetime soap “Devious Maids” in 2012. She was a diversity hire.

articles.headline: Facebook Struggles to Balance Civility and Growth
articles.snippet: Employees and executives are battling over how to reduce misinformation and hate speech without hurting the company’s bottom line.
articles.abstract: Employees and executives are battling over how to reduce misinformation and hate speech without hurting the company’s bottom line.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In the tense days after the presidential election, a team of Facebook employees presented the chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, with an alarming finding: Election-related misinformation was going viral on the site.
articles.byline: By Kevin Roose, Mike Isaac and Sheera Frenkel
